#Text=California Supreme Court upholds law hastening death penalty
#Text=Sunday , August 27 , 2017
#Text=The execution chamber at San Quentin Prison , the home to all male death row inmates .
#Text=Image : California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation .
#Text=On Thursday , the California Supreme Court upheld a ballot measure , Proposition 66 , approved by voters last November which speeds up the death penalty appeals process .
#Text=The court , however , weakened a provision of the proposition setting a deadline for appeals .

#Text=The plaintiff in the case , former El Dorado County supervisor Ron Briggs , claimed that the proposition was unconstitutional under the California Constitution which prevents ballot measures from addressing more than one subject .
#Text=The court disagreed with Briggs ' claim , writing that " Proposition 66 is more focused on a single subject " than other measures upheld by the court .
#Text=The weakened portioned of the measure would have set a deadline of five years for the appeals process .

#Text=The court wrote in its opinion for the case , Briggs v. Brown , that " provisions of Proposition 66 that appear to impose strict deadlines on the resolution of judicial proceedings must be deemed directive rather than mandatory " in order to prevent difficulties with the separation of powers .
#Text=The new measure moves habeas corpus review from the Supreme Court to the lower courts .
#Text=Habeas corpus review allows those convicted to contest procedures from during the trial process , such as possible problems with jurors .
#Text=The measure also ended public review of execution methods .
#Text=Briggs had also challenged how the proposition affects habeas corpus review , but the court ruled in favor the defendants .
#Text=Five justices , of the court 's seven , signed the majority opinion .
#Text=Two justices were defendants in the case as part of the Judicial Council and recused themselves , and two alternate justices were brought in from appeals courts in Santa Ana and Sacramento .
#Text=The council is responsible for making policy for the state 's courts .
#Text=Currently , the appeals process for death penalty cases can last for years or even decades .
#Text=The ballot measure sought to speed this up .
#Text=It could affect 15 or more inmates currently sitting on death row who have already completed the appeals process .
#Text=The state has not conducted any executions since 2006 .
#Text=A federal court imposed a moratorium on the use of California 's lethal injection method in 2006 after a challenge to the methods used .
#Text=This order remains in effect , so the state must first receive approval from the federal court regarding its method before it is allowed to resume executions .
#Text=In January a proposal to conduct lethal injection with a single drug was rejected by a state agency .
#Text=There were 747 people on California 's death row as of Thursday according to the state corrections department .
#Text=The state applies the death penalty for several crimes including murder , treason against the state , train wrecking causing death , and perjury causing the execution of another .
#Text=Lethal injection is one of two methods used by the state for executing inmates .
#Text=The gas chamber remains an option for inmates who elect that method of execution .

#Text=While voters approved Proposition 66 last November with 51 % voting yes , another ballot measure to repeal the death penalty , Proposition 62 , was rejected by voters in the same election with 53 % voting against .
